awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to  Carolyn Abbott is "Acylindrical actions on hyperbolic spaces." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Ian Agol.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The collection of symmetries of an object form an algebraic object called a group. For example, the reflections and rotations of a square form a group of size eight. Groups act on spaces: a 90 degree rotation acts on the square by turning it counterclockwise. Studying groups through the spaces on which they act leads to many questions. One could ask, for example, how many different groups act on a square? What do such groups have in common? Geometric group theory aims to answer such questions by translating the geometric properties of spaces on which a group acts into algebraic properties of the group. In this project, PI used these techniques to work towards understanding certain classes of groups, all of which act on spaces that have a particular geometric structure, called hyperbolicity.

In more detail, this projects made progress towards the broad goal of understanding groups that act on hyperbolic, or negatively curved, spaces. The key achievements of this project include building our understanding of all actions of a given group on various hyperbolic metric spaces, and finding a ”best” action of any group in a particular class of groups (called hierarchically hyperbolic) in which there has been a recent explosion of interest.

This project supported and encouraged student involvement in mathematics. During the tenure of the award, the PI was the vice president of STEM-Fam, a program supporting underrepresented minorities in STEM at the graduate and postdoctoral levels. The PI organized a seminar which facilitating the dissem- ination of research and allowed for informal discussions between early career mathematicians and senior researchers. Additionally, the PI mentored several students interested in geometric group theory at both the undergraduate and graduate level.
